msItem.title: Book of Hours, Use of Sarum
msItem.note: (with prayers in English)
Added texts on endleaves.
Latin prayer to St Apollonia for toothache added in a new hand, and, in another hand, a Latin ‘a pat[er] nost[er]’, and a note for ‘seynt rasam[us] ’ (probably St. Erasmus) has been added.

A note about ‘Curtes wyff’ taking ‘Dorothe to noros’ on the ‘Sunday aft[er] Candlemas Day in the 24th year of Kyng Henry the Eyth’ (1533). A note about wetnurse provision, written in secretary script.
A medical recipe, written in a secretary script.

Three notes, all in the same secretary hand. The first two record details about the Gavell family (Robert Gavell). The third, in a lighter ink, is a record of a horse-stealing incident from a pasture belonging to ‘my lorde of Svffolk’ in Claxton in 1535.
‘mensura longitudinis [christ]i’ with pen and ink illustration demonstrating the height of Christ.
‘Kalendar’ in same hand as later Hours; January – December, including saints as to be expected in Sarum use, with the addition of St Erkenwald (possibly London diocese).
Prayers
‘Orationi boni angeli vici’ and other prayers to guardian angels.
msItem.explicit: dei in pace requiescant Amen
P[er] [s]p[iritu]m d[omi]n[u]m n[os]tr[e] Ame[n]
deus Benedictus in secula amen
deus meus es tu tibi honor et gloria in s[e]c[u]la s[e]clo[rum]
adiuvisti me et consulatus es me

msItem.incipit: Domine deus omnipotens pater et filius et sp[iritu]s
msItem.explicit: de profundis clamamus deus misereritur n[ost]ri.

msItem.note: The Seven Five Joys of the Blessed Virgin with antiphon
Prayers to Jesus featuring the life of the Virgin Mary
msItem.explicit: luce clara tecum frui. Gloria. Amen

msItem.note: Prayers to the Seven Angels and Archangels.
msItem.incipit: In nominib[us] angelorum et archangelorum septem
msItem.explicit: Dominus vobiscum. Et cum sp[irit]u[s] tuo. Oremus

msItem.note: Prayer to the instruments of the passion preceded by English indulgence, part erased.
msItem.explicit: Qui vivis et regnas deus p[er] omnia ..[obscured]

msItem.note: Hours of the Virgin with the Hours of the Cross worked in

The Hours begins proper with the Matins, yet it begins mid-way through one of the hymns as a leaf has been removed (fragments still visible). suggesting that a page has been removed . The Little Hours are completed with ‘The Hours of the Cross’ from fol. 20v onwards. Incipit: ‘serviunt per tempora…’, (from the hymn which begins ‘Quem terra, pontus, aethera’) Explicit: ‘…ne valcamus p[er]venire p[er] do[minum] n[ost]r[u]m’.
msItem.bibl: Edition: Horae Eboracenses, pp. 38-39 for hymn; pp. 38 – 70 for hours, c.f. notes on Sarum use; pp. 44-6 for suffrages. .

msItem.note: Penitential Psalms.
msItem.explicit: d[o]min[um] n[ost]ru[m] Amen
msItem.note: Accompanied by litany (fols. 38r – 39v).
Officium Mortuorum
msItem.explicit: Recquiescant in pace amen
msItem.bibl: Edition: Broadly follows Horae Eboracenses, v. 132, pp. 99 – 111, leaving out the final three prayers.

msItem.note: Commendatio Animarum
msItem.explicit: per c[hrist]um d[o]m[inu]m no[s]trum Amen
msItem.bibl: Edition: Broadly follows Horae Eboracenses, v. 132, pp. 111 - 14

msItem.note: Psalmi de Passione Domini
msItem.rubric: psalmi de passione domine nostril ih[es]u [christ]i
msItem.explicit: per om[n]ia s[e]cloru[m] Amen
msItem.bibl: Edition: As Horae Eboracenses, v. 132, pp. 114 – 6

msItem.note: Psalter of St Jerome
msItem.explicit: et clamor meus ad te veniat. Oremus.
msItem.bibl: Edition: As Horae Eboracenses, v. 132, pp. 116 – 122 with variant closing prayer.

msItem.note: Miscellaneous Prayers
Fol. 80v has a crossed-out hymn ‘O stella maria maris’, which is crossed continually until fol. 82r.
msItem.explicit: Feliciter mereamur interire reginum. Per d[o]m[i]n[u]m

msItem.note: Prayers
Bede’s Seven Words of Christ.
msItem.explicit: god wil change it into everlastyng joy (features two crossed-out red rubric indulgences).
msItem.bibl: Edition: C. Brown, Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century, (Oxford: 1939), pp. 217-221

msItem.note: ‘O blissed god’
msItem.incipit: O blissed god yt art almiȝti
msItem.explicit: jh[es]u[s] y[t] art almiȝti nowe and ev[er] y[e] mercy. Amen jh[es]u[s]
msItem.bibl: Edition: R. T. Davies, Medieval English Lyrics: A Critical Anthology, (New York: 1975), pp. 120 – 5

msItem.note: A prayer by the Five Joys.
msItem.explicit: in heven for to have a place. Amen
msItem.bibl: Edition: C. Brown, Religious Lyrics of the XIVth Century, rev. edn. G. V. Smithers (Oxford: 1954), pp. 216 - 7

msItem.note: Fols. 93v – 96r include a sequence of charms; the promise of safety and deliverance from hell has been crossed out, yet the sequence of names and Latin phrases which would guarantee the charm’s efficacy remains intact.
The Fifteen Oes attributed to St Bridget.
msItem.explicit: for euermore in y[e] blysse. Amen. Pater noster. Ave maria
msItem.note: This is a middle English translation of the Fifteen Oes attributed to St Bridget which does not match any of the others mentioned in the IMEP, IMPEP, or Ogilvie-Thompson (1988).
Fols 99v – 100r includes a crossed-out narrative of St Gregory and a related indulgence
msItem.incipit: in illo tempore quo sanctus Gregorius
msItem.explicit: viginta milia annia sex anni et triginta sex dies or[atio].

msItem.note: Suffrages to John the Baptist, St. George, St Christopher, Mary Magdalene, St Margaret, St Catherine, and St. Barbara
msItem.explicit: d[om]inum n[os]tr[u]m Amen

msItem.note: Added texts on endleaves (ruled).

prayer (‘Domine deus omnipotens pater et filius et spiritus sanctus da michi famulo tuo N victoriam …) preceded by lengthy indulgence in English which is partially crossed-through; followed by other prayers, in a cursive formatted script, Anglicana with some secretary features; on fol. 108v, the Lord’s prayer has been added in a less regular secretary script.
A modern pencil note about an image which was removed post-accession, and is now catalogued under Bodl. Arch. F. e. 7.
pen trials; attempt at writing name ‘katerin… gavell’; at bottom of page, line reads ‘to my welbelovved [m]istrys Katerryng (?) Gavel’.
A Marian hymn in Latin (‘stella celi extirpavit …) in a bastard script; a date which reads ‘A. W. MDCL’ at the top of the page, which post-dates accession to the library.
Two notes, in now illegible text; a former pastedown.

supportDesc.collation: Seventeen quires. 1(8-3?) (first leaf missing (?cancelled), ?second leaf a former pastedown, sixth and eight leaves missing (cancelled)) (fols. i-v), 2(6) (fols. vi-xi), 3(8+1, a leaf (fol. 9) added at the end of the quire) (fols. 1-9), 4(8-1, first leaf missing, fragment remains) (fols. 10-16), 5(8) (fols. 17–24), 6(8) (fols. 25-32), 7(8+1, stub before fol. 33, leaf (fol. 41) added at the end of the quire) (fols. 33-41) | 8(8) (fols. 42-49), 9(8)-14(8) (fols. 50-97), 15(10-1, fol. prior to 102 removed and stub remaining) (fols. 98-106), 16(2) (fols.107-108), 17(2) (fols.109-110). Catchwords in same hand as main text: visible on fol. 8v (‘corpus’), fol. 16v (‘dominus’), fol. 24v (‘arantii’), fol. 32v (‘meum’), fol. 40v (‘tuii eis’), fol. 49v (‘go rudebo’), fol. 57v (‘tuas. tu’), fol. 65v (‘medum’), fol. 73v (‘neque’), fol. 81v (‘et augustus’), fol. 97v (remnant of catchword cropped off). There were probably other catchwords, but were trimmed during the production process.

layoutDesc.layout:
2 col. of 22 lines (except in calendar); ruled in pale lilac; pricking in outer margins. Ruled space
142 100 , intercolon 6 mm.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic littera textualis formata quadrata; one hand.

decoDesc.summary: "Defaced. Good miniatures, historiated and other initials." (Pächt and Alexander iii. 1087, pl. CI)
decoDesc.decoNote:
Historiated initials and full borders at main textual divisions (missing before fol. 10; fol. 31r; 42r)
Fol. 31r (Penitential Psalms). David in penitence.
Fol. 42r (Office for the Dead). Funeral scene.

Historiated initials and partial borders at other textual divisions (fols. 13r; fol. 20v; fol. 22v; fol. 24r; fol. 25v; fol. 26v; fol. 28r; fol. 57r; fol. 65v; 70r)
Fol. 13r (Hours of the Virgin). Christ praying in Gethsemane.
Fol. 20v (Hours of the Cross). Judas kissing Christ.
Fol. 22v (Hours of the Cross). Trial of Christ.
Fol. 24r (Hours of the Cross). Crucifixion. In lower border, a portrait of a man holding a quill.
Fol. 25v (Hours of the Cross). Wounding of Christ.
Fol. 26v (Hours of the Cross). Christ being taken down off the cross. In the lower border, a portrait of a woman holding a quill.
Fol. 28r (Hours of the Cross). Christ’s burial in the tomb.
Fol. 57r (Office for the Dead; Commendation of the Soul). The washing of the innocents.
Fol. 65v (Psalms of the Passion). Christ rising from the tomb.
Fol. 70r (Psalter of St Jerome). St Jerome, partially damaged through touching.

Column illuminations (fol. 99v; missing before fol. 102; fol. 102r; fol. 103r; fol. 103v; fol. 104r; fol. 105r; fol. 105v; fol. 106r)
Fol. 99v (The Fifteen Oes attributed to St Bridget). Wounded Christ standing in the tomb.
Fol 102r (Suffrages to the Saints). John the Baptist.
Fol. 103r (Suffrages to the Saints). St. George slaying the dragon.
Fol. 103v (Suffrages to the Saints). St Christopher carrying Christ across river.
Fol. 104r (Suffrages to the Saints). Mary Magdalene.
Fol. 105r (Suffrages to the Saints). St Margaret emerging from dragon.
Fol. 105v (Suffrages to the Saints). St Catherine and wheel.
Fol. 106r (Suffrages to the Saints). St. Barbara.
Decorated initials with red, blue and gold accents to mark the beginnings of new sections or prayers throughout, and red ink often used for rubrics and titles.
Inserted s.XV3/4 wood-cut image of Christ as Man of Sorrows formerly at fol. 109, removed to Bodl. Arch. F. e. 7 in 1894. Pricking on the folio indicates that it had been sewn in.

additions.p:
Notes in 15th and 16th century English hands throughout flyleaves, endleaves, and in calendar. Makes reference to the Sydney family, the Gavell family, and the Byddey family (see Provenance).
January, fol.vi recto : on the nones, the octave of St. Thomas Becket has been defaced; in the margin, a note about a saint linked to the obscured name and the ‘circumsio Domini’ has been added, but now obscured; on the 10th before the kalends, ‘Januar..’ has been written in cursive; on the 6th and 3rd before the kalends, crosses have been added, presumably to mark the dies infelix.
February, fol. vi verso : ‘dies infelix’ on 6th and 3rd before ides, and 10th before kalends; 4th February, obit. ‘Nycolay Byddey’ 1512; 10th February, obit. Robert Gavell 1538; 21st February, Thomas Sydney born 1488; pen trials at bottom of page.
March, fol. vii recto : ‘dies inffelix’ on ides, 16th and 15th before kalends; 10th March, birth of a ‘Wylelmi Sydney’ born in 1483 (here, the date has been smudged and and runs to the edge of the page; it appears to read ‘mo cccc octa[obscured] tertia)’; extensive pen trials at bottom of page.
April, fol. vii verso : ‘dies inffelix’ on 7th and 6th before ides; 25th April, nativity of ‘Edwardi Sydney’ in 1488.
May, fol. viii recto : ‘dies inffelix’ on 4th before ides, ides, and 17th and 13th before kalends
June, fol. viii verso : ‘dies inffelix’ on 6th before ides.
July, fol. ix recto : ‘dies inffelix’ on 3rd before nones and ides; 2nd July, note about ‘Thomasine Sydney’ born in 1482; the translation of the relics of S. Thomas scrubbed out on the nones and, with it, a note on the obit of Thomasine Gavell on the 8th July; 12th July, the ‘nativitas’ of Lodowisi Sydney in 1489; the nativity of Henry Sydney on the 20th July in 1529 recorded at the bottom of the page.
August, fol. ix verso : ‘dies inffelix’ on 14th and 13th before kalends.
September, fol x recto : ‘dies inffelix’ on 16th and 15th before kalends; 10th September, birth of Robertus Sydney, 1490; at bottom of page, in unconfident hand, ‘September’ is written.
October, fol. x verso : ‘dies inffellix’ on 2nd before nones.
November, fol. xi recto: ‘dies inffelix’ on 15th and 13th before kalends; 16th November, birth of ‘Ffranciscus’ Sydney in 1491; at bottom of the page, the birth of Philip Sydney recorded on the 30th November 1554.
December, fol. xi verso : ‘dies inffellix’ written on 8th and 6th before ides and 18th before kalends, and marks on 5th before nones and 2nd before kalends; 5th December birth of Nicholas Sydney in 1480; 23rd December, death of Lodowisi Sydney in 1489.
On fol. 110r, ‘A. W. MDCL’ at the top of the page.

binding.p: 224 x 157 x 7mm. Late sixteenth century binding of white parchment with gold ornament at centre at edges; ‘inboard gold-tooled centrepiece binding, probably English’. Thought to be calf leather over beech boards, with remnants of gold tooling ‘executed with a single fillet, an oval centrepiece, and two small tools’. Remnants of a Bodleian Library chain staple which is now missing. Clasps and corners also missing. Shelfmarks visible are ‘850’ in black paint, ‘Med’ in ink, and ‘SVP: ART | d:55’ and ‘ARCH: |F.5’ gold-tooled. The reference to ‘med’ and ‘5’ echo the older shelf-mark notation on fol. iiir, consistent with an early modern classification system.

history.provenance: Names mentioned in the calendar and the notes on the flyleaves mention three families: the Byddey family (1512), the Gavell family (1538), and the Sydney family (1480 – 1554) (see above, Additions) Analysis of the miniatures has dated the manuscript to the latter half or third quarter of the 15th century .

As the Sydney family’s dates are earliest, it is reasonable to assume that the book originated with them, and, with the generation who were so keen to record their children’s births and deaths in the 1480s and 1490s. As a probable conjecture for original owner this would suggest Nicholas Sydney (1447 - 1512) and his wife, Anne Sydney (Brandon) (1454 - 1497). Exact knowledge of their children is limited, but ‘Wylelim’ Sydney, born 1483, recorded at fol. vii recto, appears in the Sydney family tree. If Nicholas and Anne commissioned the Book of Hours, then perhaps they are figures included in the borders at fols. 24r and 26v.

The book evidently remained in the Sydney’s possession as it passed down between generations, and it was used to record the birth of poet Sir Philip Sydney in November 1554. Yet, at some point, it was evidently the place of record for the Gavells (and the Byddey family on one occasion). This transfer of the book — rare in a lay context — may in fact be indicative of a circle of acquaintances using the same book. There is evidence of a relationship between Sir Philip Sydney and a Thomas Gavell. The book suffered during the years of the Reformation, with pages of indulgences being crossed out and, perhaps, changing doctrine was the cause of some of the scrubbed-out saints in the calendar.
history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated to the Bodleian Library in 1620, but there is no record of by whom. Previous shelmarks 'Med ms 5', 'Th. B. 1. 12' (fol. iii recto)

recordHist.source: Description by Francesca Peacock, 2025. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue (1922). Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 448

Add binding information from Summary Catalogue.
